title: Shamed Ted Baker founder loses £66m in two days as shares slump 10%
text:
Ted Baker's founder Ray Kelvin has lost more than £66million in just two days after the struggling retailer's shares tumbled nearly 10 per cent in the wake of a profit warning.

The 63-year-old still owns almost 35 per cent of the company's stock – or 15.54m shares.

His holding was worth £144million on Wednesday, the day before Ted Baker warned its profits will be lower this year because the warmer weather has put customers off buying autumn clothes.

Ted Baker founder Ray Kelvin lost more than £66m in just two days after the struggling retailer's shares tumbled nearly 10 per cent

The firm also announced it had swung into the red in the first half with a £23million loss as revenues edged lower and aggressive discounting took its toll on the group, which has previously been one of the High Street's more resilient brands.

This prompted a 36 per cent sell-off in its shares on Thursday alone – and its stock tumbled by another 9.9 per cent, or 55p, to 500p yesterday.

After the plunge, his holding is worth £77.7million.

Kelvin was forced to leave Ted Baker – which he founded in 1988 – in March after he was embroiled in a scandal about inappropriate office behaviour following allegations of 'forced hugs' and ear-kissing from staff.

The company – which has 560 shops and concessions worldwide – has since had to overhaul its global HR policies and the legal fallout has cost it £3million so far.

Ted Baker's share price spiked to 1982p on the day he announced his resignation.

Since then it has lost 75 per cent of its value, diving from £883million to £223million. Kelvin's personal holding has plummeted from £308million to £77.7million.

The first-half loss revealed on Thursday was the first since the company listed on the stock exchange in 1997.
